discussion.content: When they state that the remote client and the server are both Windows-based, you can assume that it is RDP, since Microsoft created it.

I knew the answer would be RDP because SSH isn't built for uploading files. WHich leaves RDP as the ONLY sensible option. I agree RDP shouldnt be used for uploading files as it's way out of scope for the purpose of file uploads
You can use SSH to upload and transfer files with SCP. I think it's SSH, with the windows aspect of the question to throw you off. SCP is also in the exam objectives.

"Both the remote user and the server are using a Windows-based OS"
RDP is a proprietary protocol developed by Microsoft. Tricky question.

The easiest way to securely transfer files between the server and your computer is use Remote Desktop.
https://www.ionos.ca/help/server-cloud-infrastructure/dedicated-server-for-servers-purchased-before-102818/servers/transfer-files-using-remote-desktop/
I have never ever use RDP for copying files. Always we use at work FTP client (filezilla) RDP is more for troubleshooting. Any way I learned something new today

By default, Windows Dedicated Servers have no FTP server installed or setup. The easiest way to securely transfer files between the server and your computer is use Remote Desktop.

Click the Start menu on your PC and search for Remote Desktop Connection.
Launch Remote Desktop Connection and click on Show Options.
Select the Local Resources tab and click More.
Under Drives, check the box for your C: drive or the drives that contain the files you will transfer and click OK.
Enter your connection details and click Connect.
Once connected, open Windows Explorer or My Computer from your server and you will be able to see the drives you shared. Drag and drop files to a folder on your server to transfer the files.
No one is using remote desktop to upload files to a server.
Since when does RDP allow file transfer?

comments.content: you can map drives through the RDP client
And copy and paste is allowed through RDP... Still a ridiculous question by CompTIA

discussion.content:
Now, IF they mean the remote user is an ‘Administrator’ or other ‘Special Permissions’ user, and they’re required to be AT the server (as it’s a duty they regularly perform while at the office ON the server), then I could see using RDP. Otherwise, the Windows Server would likely already be running as an FTP Server (with the FTP Server Service running), and they’d just remotely Telnet into it.

If this is what the question means, then the question should read; ‘At the Server’.

comments.content:
I'm sorry, but all of this is just wrong. Flat out wrong.

To use RDP to transfer files from local to remote machine or vice versa, use the "Local Resources" tab before making the connection to the machine. The bottom section of Local Resources is called "Local Devices and Resources", click on the MORE button and then select the local C: drive to configure RDP to allow access to the local drive while using RDP.

discussion.content:
This is ridiculous. RDP is mainly used for troubleshooting purposes. Why would a user go through all the trouble to Remote Desktop into a server ?
#1) The System/Network Administrator should be fired for having the RDP Service running on Windows Server.
#2) Why would a user RDP into a server just to link back across the link to upload/copy over a file ? They could’ve just mapped a network drive and be done with it.

questions.question_text: A remote user is required to upload weekly reports to a server at the main office. Both the remote user and the server are using a Windows-based OS. Which of the following represents the BEST method for the remote user to connect to the server?

A technician is troubleshooting a server in the finance office that hosts an internal accounting program. The ticketing desk has received several calls from users reporting that access to the accounting program is degraded, and they are experiencing severe delays, sometimes timing out entirely. The problem has been isolated to the server. Which of the following tools should the technician use on the server to narrow down the issue?

discussion.content:
The question states, "the problem has been isolated to the server." Therefore, I wouldn't expect to see any issues with routes or latency on the network; otherwise, the problem really isn't isolated at all.

I'd think netstat would be a better choice, given it's only the server which is having problems.

"Netstat is a networking tool used for troubleshooting and configuration, that can also serve as a monitoring tool for connections over the network. Both incoming and outgoing connections, routing tables, port listening, and usage statistics are common uses for this command."

Netstat would allow the technician to quickly analyze a broad range of potential issues on the server.

If the question did NOT indicate the problem was isolated to the server, I'd agree that pathping would be the preferred answer.

comments.content:
Then, how do you account for the fact that the "problem has been isolated to the server"?
That statement, to me, means that the server is the source of the delays, hence no need to check the routes for bottlenecks. That's why I would choose netstat over pathping
Pathping is a valid option from the server side to find out outbound traffic is getting to the other end

discussion.content: pathping combines (ICMP) ping with network latency and loss over several hops, so first it does a traceroute and identifies all the hops between two points, and then it calculates the latency and loss and provides a nice report. So it is a good answer.
I guessed “pathping,” so it *must* be right.
Good explanation neo

comments.content: because rest of the answers are even more dumber

discussion.content: why pathping ?

questions.question_text: A technician is reviewing network device logs in an attempt to trace an attack that occurred on the network. Which of the following protocols would affect whether or not the technician can properly trace the attack through the network using the logs?

discussion.content: The CompTIA exams seem like a game of deception… nothing to do with actual skill or knowledge.
NTP will only give u the time, this is an odd question

comments.content: It would be hard to track the times that things happened if the times are all wrong. Silly question but its CompTIA so what did we expect from them really!
maybe these questionable times can be isolated once compared against the baseline or some other log from before....

discussion.content: CompTIA has touched on this same subject multiple times, in multiple ways. You can't put together logs from different devices in a cohesive manner if the times are different on said devices. NTP accomplishes time-sync to ensure logs can be effectively used. Besides, none of the other answers are even remotely applicable to viewing logs.
The technician seems to know what happened and only wants to trace it's history. NTP is the best answer.

comments.content: I think if the NTP is incorrect the technician won't be able to track the attack as the times would be incorrect/out. If it makes sense?

discussion.content: I chose C only because the other answers didn't make much sense. But the more I think about it I'm not sure how NTP would make much sense either. Is it that the time is 'corrupted' so it's more difficult to track when different events occured?
Wouldn't C be a better answer? You can literally track an asset tag through GPS.
Before I steal stuff, I *ALWAYS* scan my Smart card first.

Selected Answer: C
asset tracking allows real time monitoring

Selected Answer: C
Asset tracking tags would be a better answer here

Selected Answer: C
Asset tracking tags are way better way to track equipment.
selected answer c

Selected Answer: C
Asset tracking tags would allow the organization to use GPS to track their assets to see if they get stolen. Thieves might not scan a smart card to enter.

Real Asset Management’s web-based asset tracking and data capture solution plays a pivotal role in assisting organisations globally to manage and track their business critical assets. C is the correct answer

Passleader shows C (Asset tracking tags) to be correct and in the explanation they provide the following link: https://www.wexinc.com/insights/blog/fleet/gps-asset-tracking-how-to-keep-tabs-on-valuable-remote-assets-in-real-time/
Answer is B. The reader will provide real-time equipment theft alerts when it senses the asset tracking tags moving past it. The tags themselves do not provide alerts.

comments.content: Who inserts their smart card into a computer that they’re stealing? This doesn’t make sense.

discussion.content:
Option A makes no sense at all.
Option B, a smart card reader can alert security staff when a smart card holder uses the entry/exit point but it doesn't necessarily inform security of stollen equipment, nor does it imply the card holder is there to still.
Option C this will definitely inform security of any movement of the equipment beyond the set exit point.
Option D will only be effective if no one is allowed in the equipment room. Any motion in there will set of an alert. However it will be useless in area where employees move about since it will have to be deactivated during working hours. And equipment can disappear during working hours.

Even though all can provide real-time alerts, C makes more sense.

comments.content: I strongly agree with you, this is a great insight into the question C is the right answer am taking out of all this mess.
Be a good employee: Swipe your card before you steal stuff. That’s what I do!

discussion.content: "real time theft alerts" hmm...How can a smart card reader provide this?
Asset tracking tags
C. Asset tracking tag to detect the equipment being stolen
Motion detection is the best answer unless you will not move and you will not be able to get the answer. So, move on so that I can detect you.

I feel the answer should be C. A smart card is a device, used in multifactor authentication (something you have). An asset tracking tag uses RFID that can be detected by sensors, much like the devices used in retail stores and libraries, to give immediate alerts when someone tries to steal something.

comments.content: From the official Comptia Network+ student guide: "RFID asset tracking tags allow electronic surveillance of managed assets. The tags can be detected at entry/exit points to prevent theft. "

discussion.content: I think B works. Like motion detection setting off an alarm in real time, Smart Card readers can also be setup to set off an alarm in real time when used, and they include addition information from the reader like who set the alarm off. Like the quest asked for "BEST".
smart card reader because if the equipment(inside office) is attached with a smart card, then the reader alarm would go off in real time just like the way they have it in shoppig malls.

C. is the correct answer:
https://www.wexinc.com/insights/blog/fleet/gps-asset-tracking-how-to-keep-tabs-on-valuable-remote-assets-in-real-time/
Not sure about any of these answers, key word is "real time alert" which of these would let you know the moment it was stolen.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is BEST for providing real-time equipment theft alerts to the security staff?

discussion.content: Cd. You don’t use self signed for production web apps

I'm guessing because the server is cloned, you need a new certificate. Though self-signed isn't ideal, it does not state that the production server is a public-facing server. Maybe it's an internal webserver. For internal servers self-signed certificates are okay.
CE is right. I'm guessing the question is asking how to secure the VM WHILE in production. Self-signed is often used in non-production environment.
Self signed certs will fail a PCI compliance scan...
It's because a self-signed certificate gives SSL protection, so it does fit the criteria of securing the VM
self signed ?

questions.question_text: A development team has been testing a web server on a virtual server to create a web application. Once satisfied, the development team clones the entire virtual server into production. The development team needs to use HTTP, HTTPS, and SSH to connect to the new server. Which of the following should the network administrator do to help secure this new production VM? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Upgrade the firmware on the firewall.
choices.A: Disable the HTTP port in the host firewall.
